facts.fact: The original Star Wars script was rejected by every major studio before 20th Century Fox picked it up. Even Disney initially passed on it.
The Wilhelm Scream, heard in countless movies including Star Wars, was originally recorded for a 1951 Western called 'Distant Drums'.
Darth Vader's breathing sound was created by putting a microphone inside a scuba regulator and breathing through it.
The lightsaber sound effect was created by combining the hum of an old TV set with the buzz of a film projector motor.
Yoda was originally designed to be a small, green monkey-like creature before becoming the wise Jedi Master we know today.
The Death Star's exhaust port was intentionally designed as a weakness by Galen Erso, the scientist who built it.
Chewbacca's voice was created by mixing together sounds from bears, walruses, lions, and other animals.
The original Star Wars was almost called 'Adventures of Luke Starkiller' before George Lucas changed it.
R2-D2's beeps and boops were created by sound designer Ben Burtt using his own voice and electronic synthesizers.
The Millennium Falcon was originally designed to look like a hamburger with an olive on top.
Walt Disney's original Mickey Mouse was almost named 'Mortimer Mouse' until his wife convinced him to change it.
The voice of Mickey Mouse has always been provided by a man, never a woman, since 1928.
Disneyland's Matterhorn was the first tubular steel roller coaster ever built, revolutionizing roller coaster design.
The Haunted Mansion's stretching room portraits are actually painted on rubber that stretches as the room 'grows'.
Disney's 'It's a Small World' song was written by the Sherman Brothers and is the most performed song in history.
The original Disneyland opened with only 18 attractions, compared to over 50 today.
Disney's 'Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs' was the first full-length animated feature film ever made.
The Disney castle logo is based on Neuschwanstein Castle in Germany, not a Disney creation.
Disney's 'Fantasia' was the first commercial film to use stereophonic sound.
The Disney character Goofy was originally named 'Dippy Dawg' and was meant to be a dog, not a human-like character.
The word 'LEGO' comes from the Danish phrase 'leg godt,' which means 'play well' in English.
There are approximately 400 billion LEGO pieces in the world - that's about 62 pieces for every person on Earth.
The LEGO Group produces more than 36,000 LEGO elements every minute, or 2.16 million per hour.
LEGO minifigures were introduced in 1978 and have been produced in over 4,000 different variations since then.
The tallest LEGO tower ever built was 114 feet 11 inches tall, constructed in Milan, Italy in 2015.
LEGO bricks are so precisely manufactured that only 18 out of every million fail to meet the company's standards.
The first LEGO set was called 'Town Plan' and was released in 1955, featuring buildings and vehicles.
LEGO produces more tires than any other company in the world, including actual tire manufacturers.
The LEGO Group was founded in 1932 by Ole Kirk Christiansen, who started by making wooden toys.
LEGO bricks from 1958 are still compatible with bricks made today, thanks to the company's commitment to backward compatibility.
The LA Galaxy was originally going to be called the 'Los Angeles Stars' before the name was changed to Galaxy in 1995.
The Galaxy's home stadium, Dignity Health Sports Park, was the first soccer-specific stadium built in the United States.
David Beckham's Galaxy contract included a clause that allowed him to purchase an MLS expansion team for $25 million - he now owns Inter Miami CF.
The Galaxy's mascot, Cozmo, is a green alien who was originally designed to look like a space creature to match the 'Galaxy' theme.
The Galaxy won the MLS Cup in their first season (1996) and again in 2002, making them one of only two teams to win in their inaugural year.
The Los Angeles Lakers were originally called the Minneapolis Lakers because Minnesota is the 'Land of 10,000 Lakes' - they kept the name when they moved to LA.
The Lakers' purple and gold colors were originally inspired by the University of Minnesota's colors, not LA's sunset.
The Lakers have never had a losing season at home in their entire history - a streak that spans over 70 years.
Magic Johnson's famous 'baby hook' shot in Game 4 of the 1987 NBA Finals was actually called 'junior, junior sky hook' by his teammates.
The Lakers' 'Showtime' era was almost called 'Laker Time' until Pat Riley suggested the more dramatic 'Showtime' name.
The Los Angeles Dodgers were originally founded in Brooklyn, New York in 1883 as the Brooklyn Atlantics, before moving to LA in 1958.
The Dodgers got their name from Brooklyn residents who had to 'dodge' the trolley cars that ran through the city streets.
Dodger Stadium is the third-oldest ballpark in Major League Baseball and the oldest west of the Mississippi River.
The Dodgers' famous 'Think Blue' slogan was created by legendary broadcaster Vin Scully, not the team's marketing department.
Dodger Stadium was built in just 42 months, using 21,000 tons of steel and 100,000 cubic yards of concrete.
The Dodgers' 'Dodger Dog' hot dog was originally called the 'Farmer John Dodger Dog' and is still made by the same company today.
The Dodgers were the first team to have a full-time team psychologist, hired in 1988 to help players with mental health and performance.
Dodger Stadium's famous 'Think Blue' sign was originally lit with 1,200 individual light bulbs before being converted to LED technology.
The Dodgers' 'Bleacher Creatures' fan section was inspired by the New York Yankees' famous bleacher fans, but with a distinctly LA twist.
The Dodgers' spring training facility in Arizona is called 'Camelback Ranch' because it's located near Camelback Mountain in Phoenix.
